citeinfo.origin: Gerald Sanger, National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)

abstract.p: The short-tailed Albatross of the North Pacific Ocean has been near to extinction since 1933, when fewer than 100 birds were known. Recent breeding-ground counts (as high as 63 in 1967) suggest that the world population is holding on more or less steadily. The fact that some individuals spend at least part of the breeding season at sea has been ignored. Thus, the world population of the species is higher than the breeding-ground counts indicate, being perhaps as high as 75 - 100 birds.

descript.purpose: Data collected to show the Pelagic Status of the Short-tailed Albatross.
